statement.text: CO2 angiography uses carbon dioxide as an alternative contrast agent, providing adequate vascular imaging while avoiding iodinated contrast nephrotoxicity in patients with chronic kidney disease or contrast allergy.

explanation.intuition: Instead of using iodine-based dye that can damage kidneys, CO2 angiography uses carbon dioxide gas bubbles to outline blood vessels. The CO2 is simply breathed out through the lungs, causing no kidney harm.
explanation.key_insight: CO2 provides adequate imaging for most infradiaphragmatic procedures while completely avoiding contrast-induced nephropathy. It requires specialized delivery systems and imaging technique but is invaluable for high-risk patients.
explanation.technical_details: Properties: negative contrast (darker than blood), buoyant (rises in supine patient), completely non-nephrotoxic, rapidly eliminated via lungs. Technique: dedicated delivery system, patient supine with slight tilt, digital subtraction imaging, table tilting to fill dependent vessels. Limitations: inferior to iodinated contrast for fine detail, contraindicated above diaphragm (cerebral air embolism risk), can cause discomfort/pain, vapor lock possible. Use: aortoiliac, femoral, renal imaging.

clinical_features.mechanism: Carbon dioxide gas provides negative contrast, eliminated via lungs

primary_sources.title: Journal of Vascular and Interventional Radiology

clinical_pearls: Completely non-nephrotoxic - invaluable for CKD patients
NEVER use above the diaphragm (risk of cerebral air embolism)
CO2 is buoyant - tilt table to fill dependent vessels
